title: 108_hr4119
content: The Drug-Free Workplace Program Reauthorization Act of 2004 is also known as the Paul D. Coverdell Drug-Free Workplace Program. The Small Business Act is amended to extend the time period for certain programs from 2001-2003 to 2004-2006. Additionally, there are provisions for additional grants for programs in cooperation with Small Business Development Centers. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize $1,500,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2006 for technical assistance to small businesses establishing drug-free workplace programs in cooperation with Small Business Development Centers. The Small Business Act is amended to include 2-year grants under section 27, subject to annual performance reviews. Drug-Free Communities Coalitions are eligible for grants under specific conditions. The Small Business Act is amended to include grants for drug-free workplace programs and services, as well as assistance to small businesses. Section 27 is revised to remove subsection (d) and add new subsections for technical assistance. The Administrator provides technical assistance to intermediaries for drug-free workplace programs. Intermediaries must establish a data collection system to evaluate program effectiveness, including monitoring employee drug use and related issues. The Administrator provides technical assistance to intermediaries for drug-free workplace programs, including establishing a data collection system to evaluate program effectiveness. The system must address absenteeism, injury, and disciplinary problems related to drug use, with not more than 5 percent of the grant amount used for this purpose. The Administrator provides technical assistance for drug-free workplace programs, including identifying information for measuring program benefits and analyzing trends. A study and report must be compiled within 18 months of the enactment of the Drug-Free Workplace Program Reauthorization Act of 2004. The Drug-Free Workplace Program Reauthorization Act of 2004 requires the Administrator to analyze program data, identify trends, evaluate program effectiveness, and submit a report to Congress. Amendments to the Small Business Act extend deadlines for Small Business Development Centers. The Small Business Act is amended to reduce the amount from $1,000,000 to $500,000 and specifies the fiscal years 2004 through 2006. Additionally, a new paragraph limits administrative costs to 5% of the total amount available for any fiscal year under subsection (h) of section 27.
